The main benefit of literate programming that I g=
ather from reading  
earlier messages is that it makes the error messages e=
asier to read.  
Given this example:
    assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and(=
).that(n).lessThan(10))
it seems to me to be at the expense of the readabil=
ity of the tests  
(in some cases), and also likely at the expense of amoun=
t of effort  
required to code the tests. But maybe that's a good tradeoff.=


For me, the answer is that my tests don't fail often enough to warrant  
=
that extra expense. Since I'm doing TDD, assertions generally fail  
once, =
maybe a few times, during development. And while I'm developing,  
I'm pret=
ty familiar with what the test failures mean. But after that,  
failing tes=
ts are pretty rare, and I want them to be. So, I don't  
usually bother wit=
h assertion failure messages.

When assertion failures do occur, *I have to=
 look at the test anyway.*

n example here (which

   =
 assertTrue("out of range: " + n, 2 < n && n < 10)
But that's nitpicking on=
 email-code. I think I know what you probably meant. ]

if I get a failed tes=

I code the nicer failure=
 message and rerun the tests. If it's the kind

rring, however unfortunately, I'll keep the

n, 10);
... particularly if I have a similar need elsewhere in the code. I =
 
probably do. And at that point an assertion failure message, created
